subNodes.conversationText: [In a voice that sounds like a breeze soughing through the fall woods.] Stay your step, of flesh, unless you bring me fire.
I may be a thing of flesh, bark-sister, but I am one who knows and loves the forest.  What is this strange talk of fire?
You should leave, forest-friend, lest my sorrow bend and break thee.  But first hear my tale.
The dead-cold fast approaches, and my elven love lies sleeping round my roots; the sunning-forth will wake me when the dead-cold passes, but no such sun will wake him.
And this, oh flesh-thing, makes me wish to burn with him!  He was fire-friend, I fire-foe; but that which made us strange in life will make us one in the long-sleep.  Have you a fire for me?
Ah, such sorrow!  Her elven love lies dead, and she wishes to burn with him.  Sune has been known to mete out cruel desires.
Surely, though, we will not aid her? She is mad with love, and a fire could very well destroy more in this forest than she. Fey creatures are--well, fey.
[Quite frightened.] It is bad business to meddle with such beings, . I would rather be facilitating the marriage of a young barmaid somewhere.
Where is the body of your elven lover, dryad?  I do not see him.
[Coyly.] My love lies sleeping round my roots, flesh-thing.
Sleeping?  Then he is buried beneath your tree?
[Somewhat less sweetly.] Indeed, he sleeps as does a stone.
<color=blue>[Diplomacy] If he is truly sleeping, dryad, there is a chance he'll wake.  Surely you would not burn him alive?</color>
[Sorrowfully.] Alive?...But when the dead-cold comes, he'll die.
<color=red>[Intimidate] What do you mean by sleeping, fey?!  Is he dead or alive?  Answer me!</color>
[Sorrowfully.] Alive?...But when the dead-cold comes, he'll die.
<color=yellow>[Bluff] I am curious to see his face, dryad.  He must be handsome indeed to have won a heart such as yours.</color>
Yes, a face of flower-fairness. [Sadly.] But the dead-cold will take his bloom...
If he yet lives, dryad, then why not let me see him?
Nay, flesh-thing, how could you understand the love of one such as I?  Still--though I am jealous of his beauty--it makes me proud. Behold him, then!
[You hear a sound like wood breaking, and an elf, pale and haggard, materializes nearby.]

[The elf speaks slowly, as one who has just woken up from a long sleep.] Dreams of the dark earth, and the fibers of roots around my body...To taste sweet air, after that dank eternity, is almost too much.

Cruel Voeae, did you wish to kill me?  I fell asleep in your embrace, and half-woke with your roots drinking my blood like rainwater.  I ate nothing but dust for a week, and dreamt that I had become clay.
[The dryad speaks, her voice more and more resembling the sound of the leaves.] No! I did not mean to hurt you...I wished to keep you safe before the dead-cold came and drove you back to your people.
You nearly killed him, dryad.  The ways of your kind are not the ways of his.  You must let him go now.
I understand your pain, Milady, but you owe your beloved an apology--and must bid him farewell.

Gilathias returns to his flesh-things, and I to the sleep of the dead-cold. There will be no fire for us, and I do not know if I will wake in the sunning-forth...[The dryad keeps speaking, but her voice is no longer distinguishable from the sound of the wind in the trees.]
[A louder wind blows through the forest...]
I pity you, fey creature.  You did not know what you were doing.  But you must understand your error now.
If he is alive, then you are cruel to keep him captive.
Cruel?--Cruel?  Not so cruel as the dead-cold, or the fire in my heart.
Nay, flesh-thing, how could you understand the love of one such as I?
As you say.  I must move on.
I can set a fire for you.  Are you sure, though, that this is what you want?
Want...?  I want nothing except for the dreams of the long-sleep.  Make me a fire!
[You hear a sound like wood breaking, and an elf, pale and haggard, materializes nearby.]

[The elf speaks slowly, as one who has just woken up from a long sleep.] Dreams of the dark earth, and the fibers of roots around my body...To taste sweet air, after that dank eternity, is almost too much.
Gilathias, you wake!  But we were to share the deep dreams of the long-sleep together...You cannot leave me.  Nor will you!
I will not aid you in this, fey one.
[Suddenly angry.] I do not ask for much, fire-friend. I cannot touch the fire mysef; make one for me!
Foolish flesh-thing!  Then you shall try the long-sleep first!
[As the dryad steps away from her tree in fury, you hear a sound like wood breaking, and an elf materializes nearby.]
I am not convinced your beloved is dead, dryad.  I will not set a fire for you.
What do you mean, dryad?  I do not seek to harm you.
Then hear my tale, and weep, flesh-thing. [Somewhat coyly and to herself.] Perhaps 'll bring me fire?
I am curious about this dryad, <FirstName>.  She seems too melancholy for one of her kind--there is some mystery here.  It intrigues me.
Well, Gossam, we have other things to think about at the moment.  Let's go.
You are right, Gossam.  We will return--but for now we have other concerns.
I may be a thing of flesh, bark-sister, but I am one who knows and loves the forest.  What is this strange talk of fire?
You should leave, forest-friend, lest my sorrow bend and break thee.  But first hear my tale.
The dead-cold fast approaches, and my elven love lies sleeping round my roots; the sunning-forth will wake me when the dead-cold passes, but no such sun will wake him.
